40864393.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Project Rhombus is a free-to-play minimalistic rhythm game with electronic/house music to provide the experience of you telling yourself that "this is the one" multiple times with rounds lasting normally less than one minute.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game contains primary mechanics align with DDR and Stepmania where you have four directions, and must face directions in correlation to the music's rhythm. The game sports difficulties ranging from "Easy-Normal-Hard" with an overall goal to reach 60 seconds minimum in each state to unlock the hardest difficulty, "Expert".


[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The visuals are very minimal, with stages consisting of 2-3 colors that have very strong contrast to each other, enhancing the minimalistic aspect of the game. There is also a strobing background during gamplay that may be disabled in the options if you find yourself experiencing any symptoms or complications while playing.


[h1]Music[/h1]
The music is all electronic/house, with each stage containing 2-3 tracks per stage. The Easy songs are limited to the Easy stage, Normal to Normal, etc., resulting in repeating of the same songs if you're stuck on a stage. Thankfully, the music is catchy and melodic enough to keep you contained with the music, but not overtly obnoxious to prevent you from wanting to play one more round.


[h1]Pros/Cons[/h1]
+ Good selection of music for the length of the game
+ Simplistic Gameplay [easy to learn, hard to master]
+ Clean visuals
+/- Length (can play for 5-10 minutes, only one real "goal"]
- Goals are primarily self-set/minimal replayability

[h1]Similar Games[/h1]
[u]Stepmania/DDR[/u] (simple, identical mechanics)
[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/221640/]Super Hexagon[/url] (minimal, good choice in music, varied difficulty)
[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/428900/Linea_the_Game/]Linea, The Game[/url] (music focused, slightly varied in presentation)

40426214.review:
Писать обзоры в сонном состоянии так себе идея, но раз я играл в неё только в сонном состоянии, то, думаю, всё норм.

Принцип сам по себе довольно стандартен и прост: в вас с четырёх сторон летят стрелки, и вы должны вовремя с помощью клавиш-стрелок повернуться в ту сторону, где находится стрелка. Есть жёлтые стрелки, которые идут прямо, но их скорость может варьироваться, что усложняет игру, и есть синие стрелки, которые при приближении переходят на противоположную сторону. Это очень напоминает битву с Андайн из Undertale, на что в том числе намекает и надпись "in honor of Toby Fox" в описании. Но в отличие от Undertale, паттерны стрелок здесь идут в случайном порядке, что, опять же, усложняет игру. И да, они идут не в ритм, не надейтесь.

Три уровня сложности, четвёртый открывается только если продержаться хотя бы по минуте на каждом уровне, привет Super Hexagon (хотя там был открыт только один изначально, и открывалось по одному, но кого волнует). Кстати, по умолчанию музыка действует так же, как и в Super Hexagon (запускается со случайного отрезка), но можно включить, чтобы она шла с самого начала (лично мне этот вариант больше нравится). Музыка довольно неплохая, хорошо подходит (кроме той, что на нормальном).

Теперь о неприятном. Хитбокс центра довольно огромен в сравнении с полем, и порой оставляет с недоумением. Например, если в большинстве игр я понимаю, что именно мой косяк привёл к тому, что я провалил уровень, то здесь в сочетании с довольно большой скоростью некоторых стрелок (даже на лёгком, да) чаще всего возникают вопросы к самой игре. Возможно, я просто криворукое чмо, и вас таких проблем не будет. Очень редко могут случиться очень мизерные подлагивания, что тоже раздражает, но благо процент их появления довольно мал.

Итог. Чего-то прямо слишком нового вы здесь не увидите, разве что оформление. Но для бесплатной игры сделано довольно хорошо, иногда можно сыграть.

40201814.review:
This isn't your typical long song listed rhythm game like hatsune miku games, Dj maxx, etc.
This is a small have your cursor in the right place at the right time and compete against yourself for the highest survival time game, which is heavily inspired by super hexagon. Like super hexagon, though all of the notes are on beat and to rhythm, they are completely randomized, so its more skill based muscle memory than chart memorization. This game also may be a bit more difficult than super hexagon because of its use of blue notes, which swing around to the opposite side of the screen and take some getting used to. The music is very trancelike and enjoyable, with a seperate track for every difficulty (3 to start, and 1 unlockable). Its free so I definitely recommend trying it out.

Pros:

- It's a free game
- It's a rhythm game (don't let the tone deaf people writing negatively about it not being one fool you, I assure you it is)
- There are varying difficulties (i.e. sense of progression)
- You can disable the background to be solid in the settings (thank you so much for that)

Cons:

- It's very frusturating at times, which is all the time. Getting yourself used to the mechanic of the blue projectiles is quite tricky when keeping track of the normal ones (that vary in speed)

Overall: I just wanted to try it because it reminded me of Super Hexagon and boy did I have fun. I'll keep going until I have at least 60 seconds in Expert though, so still have to jump through that hoop.

Comments and Concerns: The one thing that I would like to be located in the settings is the ability to turn off the viewing of the timer while you play. The quick moving numbers psychs me out when trying to concentrate -- even if for a split second. Just throwing that out there, regardless it's a very fun game!

4分のリズムに合わせて必ず流れてくるので結果的にリズムよくキーを入力している体になり、それが独特のリズム感を生み出している。

また、3つの難易度で60秒以上耐える事で4つ目の難易度が開放されるが、この60秒という条件が絶妙で、どの難易度でも30秒程過ぎたあたりから難易度がじわじわ上昇し、一筋縄ではいかなくなってくる。

1度やりはじめるとなかなかに時間泥棒なので、時間をとって遊ぼう！寧ろ暇な時間を埋めてくれるとおもう。

39333541.review:
There is a deep satisfaction to be gained from playing, improving and (hopefully) eventually succeeding at rhythm games. As someone who has enjoyed the likes of [i]O2Jam[/i], [i]DJMax[/i] and [i]Gitaroo Man[/i] in the past, seeing this game on offer, and for free at that, meant I had to at least try it.

Speaking of [i]Gitaroo Man[/i], the core gameplay of this is almost exactly like the defense phases of [i]Gitaroo Man's[/i] stages. Arrows will approach the center of your screen from one of four directions that correspond to the background music. You are tasked with facing those arrows when they reach the center, or face an immediate game over. Fortunately, restarting takes only a short time. Regardless, it would be nice if it could be instant, rather than having a short delay.

Throw in a visual and musical aesthetic reminiscent of [i]Super Hexagon[/i], and you are left with an experience that could suck you in for quite some time, assuming you don't let the frustration get to you.

39326526.review:
[h1] Aquele rhythm game que você respeita	[/h1]
Quando um jogo com design limpo e bonito dá as caras com custo zero, um sexto sentido surge para avaliar a qualidade do que está sendo apresentado. Jogadores ficariam perplexos se propagandas ou micro transações estourassem na tela e pelo que o jogo inicialmente propõe isso é o que se espera, entretanto, Project Rhombus não se apoia nessas ferramentas e sim em uma apresentação simples e ao mesmo tempo dinâmica que tem como principal objetivo entreter o jogador.
Ok, isso pode ter soado como um elogio genérico, porém a distribuidora PsychoFlux Entertainment inova ao trazer um jogo rítmico com cenário minimalista chamativo em cada uma das músicas. Além dos cenários que possuem paletas de cores que combinam com o ritmo - certamente um ponto que chama a atenção de muitos jogadores - a presença de indicadores interativos foi uma das melhores sacadas para o título.
Outra coisa que vai agradar os jogadores é sua curva de aprendizado, os primeiros 10 minutos dão uma grande imersão e satisfação com o game.
Outro ponto que chama atenção é a aleatoriedade nas notas a serem seguidas conforme a batida acontece, essa obrigação com a improvisação prende jogadores ao fazer com que jogar uma música seja uma experiência única sempre.
No entanto, nem tudo na vida são flores e Project Rhombus peca ao deixar disponíveis somente 4 músicas.
Para ir além com o jogo, uma sugestão aos desenvolvedores seria a adição de efeitos visuais conforme o andamento das músicas para assim recompensar os adeptos ao jogo. Mas talvez, por este se tratar de uma homenagem a uma passagem do jogo [i] Undertale	[/i] acabaria perdendo um pouco de sua essência.
No final das contas, a produtora nos oferece um título  que vale a pena conferir devido a diversão que este pode proporcionar, isso tanto para os casuais quanto para os veteranos. Então baixe agora, aumente o som e aproveite o jogo, mas antes avalie essa análise positivamente caso tenha sido útil.

Simple pero retante juego musical que pondrá a prueba tu habilidad y reflejos incluso en el nivel de dificultad más bajo. La mecánica es simple: tienes que seguir con el cursor la dirección en la que se acercan las flechas al ritmo de la música. Cada nivel de dificultad (fácil, normal y difícil) tiene su propio tema y tempo. 

El más lento es el de la dificultad más baja y el más rápido el de la más alta. Echo en falta más variedad en las melodías. Pero para ser un juego gratuito está bastante bien. Me gustaría que en una versión posterior se pudiera elegir la canción que tú quieras de tu discoteca particular de música. Por lo demás, un gran juego. Totalmente recomendado.

38562281.review:
Super Hexagon + Undertale Undyne Boss Fight + Randomization = This
It's pretty easy, but it's free and IMO pretty satisfying to play.

Unlike in Super Hexagon, 64.0, etc, this game doesn't have any patterns whatsoever (it's entirely randomized). This is both a positive and a negative. It's an obstacle to entering the "flow" you reach in other games, where you've muscle-memorized the patterns and all your brain needs to do is register which one is coming up. On some days, this flow is satisfying -- on others, it's boring. Here, the minimum concentration requisite is higher (for better or for worse).
A definitive negative is that this randomization leads to awkward pauses in the arrows. I think the game could have been / could be improved by better matching the arrows to the music.

38524012.review:
Project Rhombus is a thoroughly addicting reaction game exhibiting a high polish in appearance, sound and gameplay. Since it's just as well playable when muted, the rhythm of the music is insignificant for playing efficiently. Only the beat has a determined impact, albeit a very negligible one, and that can be quickly assessed even without listening to the music.

Featuring four energetic music tracks and clean animations, the game instantly stimulates a motivation to play well to experience the gameplay flow as long as possible. It requires a bit of training at first, since the player needs to react not to the beat but at least shortly before the beat hits. Even though the gameplay is initially misleading, adapting to the slightly off-beat controls happens faster and easier than expected. Four difficulty levels; Easy, Normal, Hard and an unlockable Expert level let everyone explore his skill level and improve on that.

Most importantly though, Project Rhombus can be tough but is always fair. A run consists of a barrage of straws that can each break the camel's back, constantly trying to throw the player into a state of panic. It's an incredibly fun and encouraging game for the right people.

(Completed Easy, Normal and halfway Hard; Expert still locked)

38361926.review:
Games like this... Games like this... I fucking loves games like this. If anyone remembers Super Hexagon, if you liked that, you will absolutely love this.

The music is great, it's fun to play to the beat of an electronic song such as the one in Normal Difficulty. 

Just watch the trailer video for the game and you will probably learn all the rules of the game just from that. The only thing left out is that you use arrow keys to control where you point, but I was able to figure that out from the video itself as most gamers are used to either arrow keys or WASD, so at most it should take people 2 to 3 tries to figure out how to play, maybe add one or two if they have never touched a computer before.

If you think you're going to beat this game no problem, leave. Just leave. It's a challenge. I laugh at myself when the game tricks me not with just the blue arrows that switch sides when they reach the half way point, but also the speed of the normal arrows being changed so that you miscalculate the order in which they get to you. You will be tricked over and over and over by this game.

Games like this is where there isn't too too much to say about the game. You face the arrow when it hits you and if you get blindsighted, game over, try to last for 60 seconds. This is one of those games where you can't say much about it, other than it's good. It just is.

38356289.review:
After getting 60+ seconds on every level including expert quickly, I can say that this game is quite fun, but lacking. The music is enjoyable, and the background visuals look nice at first, until you realize that you need to turn it off because it's so distracting. The settings menu really needs to be more visible, it took me ~20-25 minutes to realize it existed. After turning it off I was able to actually beat the harder levels. I don't think it's quite right to call it a rhythm game, since there are zero rewards for actually hitting the 'notes' at the correct time. The way the approach rate changes at the later levels is extremely off-putting and it's probably the reason it took me as long as it did to beat everything.

7/10.

[b]A free, simplistic rhythm game about blocking arrows with WASD or the directional keys that tests ones reaction time.[/b] You can play the game with a controller too using the D-pad or either of the two analog sticks.

The game's simply just about blocking arrows and surviving for as long as you can on the 4 songs included. The 4 songs are tied to the 4 difficulties, Easy, Normal, Hard, and Expert; the latter being unlocked once you survive each mode/song for at least 60 seconds, kind of like how Super Hexagon did their level unlock requirements. I survived 60+ seconds on Expert and I didn't see an actual end-game to it telling me I beat the game so I'm not sure if a completion screen kind of thing even exists.

It's free, short, can be incredibly challenging, and is less than 150MB in file size.

38261682.review:
I know I'm definitely not the first to say this, but this is pretty much like playing Super Hexagon whilst taking copious amounts of LSD.
If you have epilepsy though, don't worry, as their is an option to turn on a flat background instead of having a seizure inducing eye murderer. Not saying I don't like that.

Although plain, it is visually appealing, and me being a fan and creator of electronic music and dubstep (and the fact I like Hinkik), I love the soundtrack. The art style of the game is minimalistic but vibrant and colourful, and very sleek. It's optimized very well, and runs at 1080p60, which (unless you have a desktop or laptop that doesn't support it) should be the same for almost any PC, as it is easy to run.

The only real flaw is that the game hasn't much to offer right now, only having 4 levels of difficulty with 1 level and song each. The extreme difficulty is locked until you have achieved more than 60 seconds on each difficulty, and while fair, there is one big flaw with this game currently which affects that.

Whilst only really affecting the hard difficulty, but sometimes affecting easy and normal, the beats seem almost randomly placed. The hard difficulty song doesn't even have that much higher of a BPM compared to the others, and because of this, almost desperately tries to be hard by spamming untimed notes at you to make it hard. This kind of ruins hard difficulty, and makes extreme harder to unlock as a result.

But, this game is not long released, and most flaws will (hopefully) be fixed in time. Overall, a good game with sleek and colourful art, easy to pick up and play because of simple controls, although still hard, but can get very repetitive and boring within an hour because of the lack of content. The timing is good for easy and medium, although could be better, but hard difficulty seems like a jumbled mess of notes being chucked at you in quick succession to make it hard, and a fairly average song compared to the others. I would still recommend you try this out, though, and as I said, this game has not long come out, so it should be tweaked and fixed soon enough.

38256313.review:
A pretty unique game (a first for concepts that I never seen before) that does deliver some mildly interesting content for a free game. But while the aesthetics are quite colourful, it gets pretty bland fast as you'll realise it's pretty minimalistic, content-wise. But that shouldn't be surprising considering the game is barely above 100MB in size.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
Project Rhombus pits you in the middle of a diamond / rhombus as you try to block arrows from reaching the middle and making you fail. The arrows have variable approach rates and some can jump to the side opposite it originally came from, to add to difficulty. As a rhythm game, such concept is unique (at least for me) as I never seen it executed before. But that is just about it for the variability of gameplay as you seemingly block arrows to no end. The lack of progress / stat-tracking bar the timer gives little incentive to keep retrying.

[h1] Content & Miscellaneous [/h1]

As mentioned before, Project Rhombus is very minimalistic in its current state when it comes to content as there are only 3 available levels with 1 harder one locked behind some time dedication. Since there is a lack of progress-stat related features except the timer, there is little incentive to get to it. (I did it anyway, but I personally believe this would ward away casual players)

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

- Minimalistic design that's pretty aesthetic; pleasing on the eye except for the epileptic ones
- (A bit of a con) incredibly simple gameplay means no need for a tutorial
- (A bit of a con) highly variable arrows allows gameplay to be based on skills. Their random appearances throughtout the song COMPLETELY demolishes the thought of memorising the song to beat it, which is sort of nice.
- Music sounds pretty nice, needs more variety though.

[h1] Gray zone: [/h1]
- Since there was no tutorial, gameplay was initially confusing. Despite the incredibly simple gaming, a well-highlighted tutorial with maybe slow-motion and / or a simple page describing the game with gameplay gifs would have new players, since all games ought to have some sort of a tutorial
-The variability of the arrows means that not only you can't memorise the level, but you also can't play-match the arrows to the beat in your head when it does appear. Some sections are loaded with arrows while others are also bare, sometimes in the part of song when you expect it to be "heavy". That can sometimes throw you off.

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
- Except for yesterday (11/12/17) update, the game has literally no configuration ability which can block enjoyment of users who likes to customise their game experience. The option should be revised in the future again in accordance with new changes.
-Lack of progress tracking: Project Rhombus has only one way to track highscore and that's via a timer; how long you have survived into the song. The lack of scoring - points, checkpoints, leaderboards gives little incentive to retry, except for the expert level. Even then it's almost not enough. 

[h1] Verdict [/h1]

Project Rhombus is a neat, indie rhythmic game that is worth a try as there is literally no "risk" even among F2P games, as it is only ~110 MB as of now. However when compared to other popular mainstream entries like Cytus, Osu, or even Geometry Dash, it is pretty "stale". I suggest trying it and adopt a "wait-n-see approach", hence why I am recommending this game for everybody.

P.S: The developer(s) should have a Trello page to detail the game development plans and / or discuss future features with other players. Steam discussion can be a start as a forum.

38222657.review:
Calling this title a rhythm game is kind of misleading for two reasons. If you go into [i]Project Rhombus[/i] expecting that the game wants you to hit the corresponding arrow key right as the colored arrows reach the middle of the screen, then you’ll be having a bad time.

The objective is to actually have your central arrow facing the direction of the incoming arrow when the beat lands, which directly means that you have to orient your own arrow at the very latest a split second before impact. So yes, it’s a rhythm game in the sense that the encroaching arrows always land on the beat, but rhythmic gameplay is not required from the player.

There is however a cardinal sin the game commits by introducing varying speeds between arrows, so you can’t concentrate on the arrows in the order they appear. Some arrows can be slow as molasses and hang on screen for multiple seconds, getting overtaken by arrows that show up later but travel faster. This, coupled with the mechanic where blue arrows switch their trajectory mid-flight, makes it incredibly disorienting when trying to concentrate on which arrow is going to land next. And the reason why I call it a cardinal sin is because the speeds at which the arrows travel also don’t seem to be determined by the rhythm itself, again taking away from the claim of [i]Project Rhombus[/i] being a rhythm game. Because the speed of the arrows is also not determined by the background music’s intensity or anything, which incidentally can quite often end up not featuring any percussive sounds, making keeping the rhythm even more difficult for people who aren’t musically skilled. 

I can’t in good conscience not recommend a free game, since the most you’ll invest in it is your own time if you’re willing to enjoy a fairly simplistic arcade mechanic. There are things here that I really don’t like, but then again, you might like it better than I did.

38222587.review:
Fairly good game however I do have a few complaints. (ideas at the end of review)

Advantages

1: Songs are very catchy and easy to memorise, but without consistent starting points memorising songs is a next to useless ability.

2: Gameplay is quite solid, and the controls feel very fluid and fast. Not once have I ever died because of the controls, only due to me misreading the arrows. This brings me to my next point, The time you have to react to the arrows is perfect in the earlier levels, but it seems slightly unfair in the later difficulties. I understand that this is to make them harder, but at hard diff I expected slightly more reaction time then the given amount. Just a tiny amount more would make it more fair in my opinion.

3: The game doesn't have an extreme amount of movement and colors in a level, but there is enough going on that you don't tune out or lose focus. There are constantly new colors and movement that keep you engrossed in the game and paying attention to what's on screen at any given time.

Disadvantages

1: Background is fairly distracting in the later levels. For some reason hard diff onwards has a background that changes a lot faster than the previous ones. This could be to make it harder to get a high score, but it changes slightly too fast and irritates my eyes. This means i have to take breaks every so often so i don't hurt my eyes, and causes me to lose my focus.

2: The arrows arent synced up to the music. It isn't clear what beat the arrows actually follow, and more than once i've caught myself trying to time my movements to the music rather than the incoming arrows.

3: The level starts at random points in the song, which i guess is to mix it up so the game doesn't get boring. The problem with this however is that it makes it quite hard to build up muscle memory. This does make sense with the game only having only 4 levels, but i hope when more levels get added this issue is fixed.

4: Lack of levels. Only 4 levels are currently in the game, but it did just come out so im giving it a free pass on this issue. (for now)

Ideas

1: One review made by another user earlier had the idea of the following level design: Instead of trying to get 60 seconds on all levels to unlock the 4th level, maybe getting 60 seconds on easy unlocks another diff called easy 2. After that comes easy 3. This could continue onto normal and hard and the 4th diff. That way the game has quite a few levels and the difficulty ramp up isnt so big, just so the newer players to rhythm games don't find it as hard to progress and develop their skills.

2: While the music isn't bad and actually quite catchy, it isn't exactly memorable. Some of the songs seem like a few random sounds were thrown together. Nothing wrong with electronic songs as they quite fit this game and the rhythm game genre as a whole, But maybe consider adding songs that sound more memorable. Not quite sure how to put it, but some of the songs don't seem to fit that well in my opinion. There are definitely some better songs that would fit well but i can't think of any off the top of my head.

3: Maybe add some sort of reward system? Beating your highscore might get boring after a while. One idea i had is that you could add a point system that rewards you points every 10 seconds for staying alive in the later gamemodes. These points could be redeemed for skin packs that change the background, or customizable backgrounds/arrow colors. If you really want to make money you could add the ability to purchase these points to help support the dev(s).

Conclusion

This is a good game, but the flaws are holding it back more then they should. 

However, despite the flaws the game is still fairly decent and has virtually no bugs + better gameplay than a lot of stuff i've seen throughout 2017. I would recommend this because i have high hopes for the dev(s) as they have created a truly great game that I know will go through some great changes.

38211600.review:
Very fun and engaging, requires a fair bit of muscle memory and reaction timing to place the direction of your arrows to the corresponding ones. Much like a dance arcade game, this functions similarly in that you have to time the arrow to the patterns of the music. 

Be warned, the tempo of the modes above do get very tricky. And once it's game over, you have to try again and again to beat your score. This IS a game of survival. But don't be fooled by how monotonous that sounds, the soundtracks are very captivating even if you're not a fan of dance music, and they don't fully reset every time you make another effort to beat your score - so it does try to make each attempt different, especially with the RNG of the arrows and their speeds. Much of the theme of the actual gameplay seems very reminiscent of the Undyne boss battle from Undertale where you have to guard against the attacking arrows and have to switch sides from the blue ones. Which can catch you off guard a lot.

For a free game, this is definitely a must-try. The animations are perfect, the sounds are great and the visuals are colourful and captivating. There is complete controller functionality involved, too - if you have one. As well as rumble. Although, if you suffer from dyslexia or hypersensitivity, then the arrows, the bright colours and the animations might be a bit much. That being said, this is a great, challenging game and a fun past-time to get stuck in with if you're bored and in need of a buzz. 

8/10 

EDIT: One thing that does bug me, though, is the fact that the game isn't skill-based or based off of a score of how many arrows you managed to get in the time you had. Because every arrow is randomised and with it being a time-based score system, it's hard to get into the grips with the level of difficulty at times with how many arrows are being thrown at you from all directions. The arrows can be paced differently which can screw with your mind. So you either have the attention span and reaction time of a god, or you legitimately need to get better each time. 

Another thing is that there doesn't seem to be any ranked system. Like an online scoreboard where you can share your time with your friends, etc. But as said previously, this game at its current state seems to be a pure past-time. And for a game that's free, this is what you get. So it's not all that bad.

38204787.review:
A rhythm game this is not. You have to block arrows that fly at you by moving around a shield using the directional buttons, but as you can move the shield around whenever you want the only rhythmic aspect is the beat the arrows make impact with the center at. Kind of. The syncopation is *far* from perfect, and the off-beat ticking noise made with each blocked arrow is distracting enough that it makes keeping the beat actively more difficult. Furthermore, because you have to maneuver the shield in front of any given arrow *before* it arrives, if you fall into a groove and start pressing buttons on the beat, you will die immediately.

But it's free, yeah, so if you really, really liked Super Hexagon, and that one boss battle in Undertale then give it a try, but if you're expecting a rhythm-based skill game, this isn't it.

38196616.review:
I'm going to echo what another user said in their review: this is not a beat-matching game. Although the incoming arrows go with the rhythms of the soundtrack, your input does not. This can really throw you off if you're used to matching your inputs to the music as one would expect from a rhythm game. In addition, this is not conveyed to you at any time as there is no tutorial or instructions provided.

The direction of the incoming arrows is also misleading as they don't "fit" into the middle diamond, making it rather misleading. I think the game could also benefit from color-coding arrows that have varied speeds. This would improve things but I would have much preferred beat-matching input gameplay overall.
38196616.developer_response:
Hi there! As you said, this game is far from beat-matching. You have to face the arrows before it reaches you, rather than pressing the button along the beat. We'd like to suggest you to think of 'blocking' the arrows.

However we admit that players might be confused because we stated Project Rhombus as "rhythm game" on the store page, so we've recently removed that phrase from the description. We're sorry.

And about the "color-coding"; we've actually considered to differ the color of the arrows responsive to the speed, as you say. But we're worried that the screen would get too complicated, so we kept our current state. Background effects and arrows' color difference couldn't coexist. We adopted the former alternative, and that's all.

Thanks for the feedback, and we'll keep try to improve this game. Take care!

38148191.review:
首評(๑•̀ㅂ•́)و✧GET√
配色和操作界面很喜歡、以及很簡單的操作（雖然現在只能玩easy）：阻擋向中心前進的箭頭。從左邊向右過來的箭頭→、要按←才能阻擋、考驗習慣的一點；藍色的箭頭會突然跳到相反方向，→的箭頭會在途中轉向成為←，需要按→才能阻擋（還好每個都是180°變化、而不是隨機）；黃色的箭頭不會改變方向，但是速度不一樣，一個很慢的箭頭可能會吸引你的注意力、然後疏忽了另一個方向的箭頭。

音樂的話每個level是不一樣的，後面有一個需要解鎖才能玩的leve。（其他模式堅持60s即可解鎖）差不多一共四首歌、失誤后重開BGM是連續的、不會重置。
打擊特效差不多8分
【Normal的時候就有點難度了、總感覺操作和節奏不在同一拍子上。打不過然後放棄了QXQ

總之是一款質量比較好的免費遊戲了、如果之後還能持續更新的話就很棒棒的啦♪(･ω･)ﾉ
